items.label: Standard Model
items.summary: A wall-mounted 3D model that presents the Standard Model of particle physics in a clear, physical layout, turning an abstract framework into a tangible object. Designed to be both printable and educational, it emphasizes structure and relationships rather than decorative detail.

description: This collection brings together a range of 3D models created during my early work in Blender. Each piece was built with a specific purpose, from simple objects intended for 3D printing to assets designed for animation and game environments. The collection is not centered on a single style or outcome, but on learning how digital form works across different contexts. Earlier models focus on basic structure, lighting, and scale, while later ones begin to account for motion, function, and narrative use. Taken together, the work documents a gradual shift from experimenting with tools to understanding how design decisions support real-world and virtual applications.
story: I started using Blender without a defined goal, beyond wanting to understand how 3D objects are constructed. The first models were simple and practical, often made so they could be printed or physically tested, which helped clarify how digital geometry translates into real space. As I grew more comfortable, I began creating characters and props for small animations and game scenes, where models needed to work within a larger system. Each project added a small lesson that stayed with me, whether about lighting, surface detail, or how form can suggest use or weight. Looking back, the collection reads as a timeline of that learning process, showing gradual improvement, experimentation, and a growing sense of control rather than a polished end result.
summary: A personal collection of 3D models made while learning Blender, focused on understanding form, scale, and how digital objects function across different uses. It serves as a record of skill development rather than a single, unified project.
title: 3D Models Collection
name: 3D Models Collection

items.label: The Vortex
items.summary: This was basically an animation test of a character jumping off a cliff, but the real goal was to play with camera movement, staging, and perspective. It shows the character from a bunch of different angles and in different poses so I could practice movement, timing, and action.

items.label: Easter Bunny
items.summary: This was a goofy little animation I made that imagines the Easter Bunny as the unlikely hero of the Easter story. It shows the bunny stumbling upon Jesus after the crucifixion and saving Him, basically giving a ridiculous alternate “origin story” for the Easter Bunny and why he becomes such a symbolic character. It’s meant to be playful, weird, and not taken too seriously.

items.label: Santa
items.summary: This one is a darker, funny short where Santa spends the entire year obsessively trying to lose weight… only for Christmas to roll around and reveal that he has a full-blown cookie addiction. It’s a ridiculous, exaggerated take on Santa with a slightly messed-up sense of humor.

items.label: Greenhorn V1
items.summary: This was my first attempt at what Greenhorn as a show could look like. It has a lot of Cyanide & Happiness vibes in tone and style, kind of crude, simple, and punchline-driven.

items.label: Greenhorn Uncanny
items.summary: Another experiment with Greenhorn, but this time I pushed the characters toward a much more human, slightly unsettling style. It’s basically me exploring how weird the show could feel visually.

items.label: Greenhorn Less Animated
items.summary: This version was closer to a moving storyboard than a full animation. The characters look very different, and the focus was more on storytelling and beats rather than fluid animation.

items.label: Funeral
items.summary: A silly sketch about a jerk’s funeral. It leans into dark humor and just kind of plays with the idea of how people might actually feel when someone awful dies.

items.label: Timeline 7 – Cheap Version
items.summary: When I thought Timeline 7 might become an animation, I made this super rough, cheap-looking version just to get the idea out and see what it might feel like.

items.label: Timeline 7 – Slightly Better Version
items.summary: Same idea as the cheap version, but this time I realized backgrounds kind of matter, so I actually hand-drew them and bumped the quality up a bit.

items.label: Channel 5 News
items.summary: This was a lip sync animation test using a Bo Burnham song. Mostly just me practicing mouth shapes, timing, and expressiveness.

items.label: Bassakwards
items.summary: Another lip sync test, but this time using a Tech N9ne track, which meant faster pacing and trickier timing. It was mainly about pushing accuracy and rhythm.

description: This collection brings together a range of animations produced across different periods, tools, and creative goals. It includes 3D models and scenes developed in Blender alongside 2D animations focused on timing, clarity, and visual communication. Some works are polished and complete, while others function more as studies—short explorations of movement, structure, or technique. Together, they show how ideas evolve when approached through different dimensions and constraints. The collection is intended for viewers interested in process as much as outcome, offering a clear look at how visual ideas are tested, refined, and sometimes left intentionally unresolved.
story: I created these animations at different points while learning, experimenting, and working through specific visual problems. Some started as technical exercises—understanding lighting, rigging, or motion curves—while others came from a desire to translate an idea into something that moved and felt coherent. Working across both 2D and 3D helped me think more precisely about space, pacing, and intent. This collection isn’t meant to present a single style or conclusion, but rather to document how my approach to animation has changed over time, and what I’ve learned by building things that move instead of just imagining them.
subtitle: A personal archive of motion studies, experiments, and finished pieces across 2D and 3D.
summary: A curated collection of animations created over time, spanning 2D work and 3D models built and animated in Blender. Each piece reflects a specific problem explored through motion, form, or timing.
title: Animation Collection
name: Animation Collection

items.label: 1. In The Beginning
items.summary: This page shows the Big Bang, marking the origin of the universe and the start of space, time, and matter.

items.label: 2. Building Blocks
items.summary: An overview of the standard model, introducing the fundamental particles and forces that make up everything in the universe.

items.label: 3. Stars and Galaxies
items.summary: Stars form from clouds of gas and dust, grouping into galaxies that shape the large-scale structure of the universe.

items.label: 5. Earth Science
items.summary: Earth’s geology, atmosphere, and oceans interact as a system, shaping the planet’s surface and long-term stability.

items.label: 9. Cambrian Period
items.summary: Life rapidly diversifies, with most major animal body plans appearing in the fossil record.

items.label: 22. Prey to Predator to Conquerer
items.summary: Humans transition from vulnerable animals to dominant hunters and tool users.

items.label: 23. Mesopotamia // Indus Valley
items.summary: Early river civilizations develop agriculture, cities, and written systems to manage growing societies.

items.label: 24. Ancient Egypt
items.summary: A centralized civilization built around the Nile, defined by long-lasting institutions and monumental architecture.

items.label: 25. Akkadian Empire // Babylonian Dynasty
items.summary: Empires form through conquest and law, spreading shared systems across large regions.

items.label: 26. Vedic Period // Shang Dynasty
items.summary: Religious traditions, social structures, and early states take shape in South and East Asia.

items.label: 27. Ancient Greece
items.summary: Independent city-states and vast empires develop contrasting approaches to governance and culture.

items.label: 28. Persian Empire
items.summary: Independent city-states and vast empires develop contrasting approaches to governance and culture.

items.label: 49. Quantum Revolution
items.summary: New theories overturn classical physics and redefine our understanding of reality.

description: This coloring book traces major moments in history through a series of hand-drawn illustrations. Each page focuses on a specific period or event, presenting information in a simple, visual way that can be engaged with by coloring. The drawings were made on an iPad using an Apple Pencil and then compiled into a printed format. The goal was to make the scope of history feel more manageable by breaking it into individual pages that invite slower, more focused attention. It’s meant for anyone curious about how large stretches of time and events connect, from the beginnings of life to the stories that shaped the world.
story: I started this project after finishing work on my TV pilot, during a period when I was watching a lot of PBS Eons and reading about science and early life. I missed drawing, especially the slower background work I had done on Greenhorn, but I’ve always had a hard time making art without a clear purpose. I tend to work better when there’s a defined structure behind the idea. The coloring book came out of that mix of curiosity and restlessness. I liked the idea of laying out the history of everything, one page at a time, in a format people could spend time with. For a while, the project felt steady and satisfying—the research, the drawing, and the accumulation of pages. Over time, though, it started to feel more like an obligation than an exploration, so I stopped working on it. In hindsight, it served its role. It gave me a reason to draw again, to approach history in a different way, and to value the process even though the book itself remains unfinished.
subtitle: A Coloring Book
summary: A hand-drawn coloring book that maps major moments in history, designed to make large timelines feel more approachable one page at a time. The project functioned as a structured way to return to drawing and research, even though it was never fully completed.
title: History of everything
name: History of everything

description: Greenhorn is an animated dark comedy-drama about Jeff Wyatt, a sixth grader forced to navigate grief, crime, and moral decay in the icy Alaskan town of Greenhorn. After accidentally killing a man, Jeff is blackmailed into joining a small-town gang, dragging his fractured family into a world of violence and manipulation. The series mixes grounded emotional storytelling with sharp humor, drawing tonal inspiration from Breaking Bad, South Park, and Rick and Morty. Beneath its absurdity runs a story about power, guilt, and the limits of control—how ordinary people rationalize extraordinary wrongdoing. The project is designed for adult animation audiences who appreciate shows that balance comedy with moral consequence and psychological realism.
story: This story began as a thought experiment that shifted forms countless times before becoming Greenhorn. I started with the feeling of pressure—wanting to tell a story that felt big while being able to make it entirely on my own. Film was too expensive, too dependent on others, so animation became the path forward. After watching Breaking Bad and Rick and Morty, I became fascinated by how both could balance humor and despair within a single frame. The sad endings of Futurama and Rick and Morty stayed with me, the ones that lingered long after the joke was over. I wanted to build something that could carry that same weight, but through characters that felt painfully human despite their absurdity. Over time, Greenhorn grew into a study of how good intentions curdle under pressure and how easy it is to justify doing the wrong thing for the right reason. Each rewrite brought it closer to the story I saw in my head—the one about a kid who thinks he’s coasting through life but ends up steering straight into hell.
subtitle: A TV Pilot
summary: An Alaskan middle schooler accidentally kills a man and is pulled into a spiraling world of crime, power, and consequence, turning a small town into his personal battlefield.
title: Greenhorn
name: Greenhorn

description:
Mind Adrift is a short-form narrative work centered on cognitive decline and disorientation, told from the inside rather than observed from a distance. It follows a person who is still present in the world—surrounded by family, routines, and familiar spaces—but increasingly unable to connect those pieces into a stable sense of reality. Time slips, relationships blur, and moments repeat or contradict one another without warning.

The project is less about plot progression and more about structure and perspective. Scenes loop, reset, or fracture in ways that mirror how memory fails in real life. The goal is not to explain the condition or resolve it, but to place the audience inside that experience long enough to understand its logic and weight. It is designed for readers interested in character-driven narratives, psychological realism, and stories that prioritize internal experience over external action.
story:
I made Mind Adrift because I wanted to explore what happens when memory becomes unreliable, not as a twist, but as the central condition of the story. I wasn’t interested in dramatizing decline from the outside. I wanted to write from a place where confusion feels reasonable and persistence feels like effort.

The process focused on restraint. I avoided explanations and leaned into repetition, small contradictions, and moments that don’t fully land. Writing it meant paying attention to how often we rely on memory to confirm who we are, and how unsettling it is when that system breaks down. This project became a way to slow that experience down and examine it without trying to fix it, letting the gaps and resets speak for themselves.
subtitle: A Story of Forgetting and Holding On
summary: Mind Adrift is a narrative project that explores what it feels like to lose continuity with your own life while still moving through it. It focuses on memory, identity, and the quiet confusion that comes from trying to stay oriented when your mind no longer cooperates.
title: Mind Adrift
name: Mind Adrift

description: Timeline 7 is a sprawling science fiction novel set hundreds of years after a catastrophic global collapse. The story follows a future civilization struggling to rebuild from the ashes of war, plague, and corruption. Human survivors, fractured into evolving species and new hierarchies, rediscover power, morality, and identity amid shifting political and biological landscapes. Through multiple intersecting perspectives—a soldier, a scientist, and a sentient machine—the book explores how progress and destruction often walk hand in hand. Written for readers who enjoy world-building and layered timelines, Timeline 7 examines the cyclical nature of humanity’s rise and fall with an eye toward resilience and reinvention.
story:
This was the first long project I ever truly finished. I began it in Anchorage during long, quiet hours at a news station job that left me more time than purpose. When I moved to Kansas City and took a telemarketing job I didn’t like, the story became an escape. By the time I finished it in Colorado, it had followed me through three states and several stages of who I was becoming. The original idea came from childhood—stories I imagined on a swing set about futuristic heroes fighting impossible wars. Those fragments stayed with me until I decided to give them a world and a structure.

Writing Timeline 7 taught me more about storytelling than anything else I’ve done. I didn’t know exactly how it would end, and in truth, it never quite did. I even started a sequel that I’ll probably never finish. Reading it later, I realized the story wanted to be something else—a graphic novel or maybe a video game—something more visual and alive than a book could hold. Still, finishing it mattered. It was proof I could see something through from beginning to end, even if I later learned it needed a different form.
subtitle: Across time, technology, and survival—what remains of humanity fights to define itself again.
summary: A post-apocalyptic science fiction story about humanity’s struggle to rebuild after self-destruction, told through intertwined lives across generations and technologies. It’s a personal milestone as much as a narrative one—the first complete story of a lifelong idea.
title: Timeline 7
name: Timeline 7

description: ChewSense is an iOS app that helps people slow down while they eat and pay more attention to their habits. It uses the motion sensors in AirPods to pick up chewing—mainly through X-axis acceleration—and gives gentle alerts when someone might be eating too fast. The app records motion and optional video so it can learn a person’s eating pattern and adjust over time. The goal is simple: improve digestion, avoid overeating, and make meals feel more mindful without asking the user to track anything manually.
story: This project started from an idea I’d been thinking about for years. I originally assumed I’d have to build my own hardware to detect chewing, which is why I bought a 3D printer and began experimenting with custom sensors. That approach got complicated fast. Instead, I looked for something people already use every day. When I found out AirPods could actually pick up chewing through their motion data, I tested it and saw that the X-axis readings were consistent enough to use. From there, I built two iOS app versions that could record motion and video while someone eats. Working through it showed me that you don’t always need custom hardware—sometimes the tools we already have are good enough to bring an idea to life.
subtitle: Using AirPods and motion data to help people slow down and eat more mindfully.
summary: An iOS app that uses AirPods’ motion sensors to detect chewing and help users eat more mindfully by slowing down their pace.
title: Chew Sense - Data Collection and Labelling
name: Chew Sense - Data Collection and Labelling

description: MediLedger is designed around a simple idea: most of what you need to do with your medication shouldn’t require opening an app. With interactive widgets, you can log a full or half dose, check how many pills you have left, see when your refill is coming up, and set up different widgets for different medications. The app handles both prescription and non-prescription meds, tracks strength and dosage, and keeps a full history of what you’ve taken. Everything syncs through SwiftData across iPhone, iPad, and Mac, and it works offline when it needs to. You can customize what each widget shows, set up alerts for refills, and rely on automatic calculations to keep your supply accurate without any extra effort.
story: This started as a project to see how far I could push a widget-first approach. I wanted something simple enough to test the idea but useful enough that the effort felt worth it. Medication tracking made sense—it’s structured, it matters day to day, and most interactions are quick. I spent a lot of time figuring out how much a widget could handle: what buttons made sense, what info people would need at a glance, and how to keep things clean without stripping away control. The goal wasn’t to build a perfect app; it was to learn what happens when the widget becomes the main interaction surface. Eventually, I want this to connect with Trackables so all these small bits of daily data live in one place and start forming patterns that actually help people. It’s still early, but it feels like the right direction.
subtitle: Widget-first medication tracking built for everyday reliability.
summary: MediLedger is a medication management tool built around interactive Home Screen widgets. It lets users log doses, track supply, monitor refills, and sync data across all Apple devices. Designed for simplicity and precision, it shifts medication tracking from the app itself to the widget, making daily adherence faster and more accessible.
title: MediLedger
name: MediLedger

description:
TowardBetter.me is a platform designed to help women find supportive communities around life transitions, personal growth, and difficult moments that are often navigated alone. I was brought on to build an announcement page that could clearly communicate the mission of the project while laying the technical groundwork for what would eventually become a larger, authenticated platform. The goal was to create something simple, welcoming, and trustworthy—an entry point that felt intentional rather than promotional.

The site was built with React and Next.js, with Firebase Authentication integrated to support future user accounts and onboarding flows. From the beginning, the focus was on clarity and structure: clean UI, predictable behavior, and a codebase that could evolve without needing to be rethought later. This project served as both a public-facing introduction and a technical foundation for what TowardBetter.me would grow into.
story:
This was the first project I worked on after returning to the U.S. from Australia, and in a lot of ways it marked a reset for me. Coming back, I wanted to be intentional about the kinds of projects I took on and the kinds of systems I helped build. TowardBetter.me stood out because it wasn’t about chasing features—it was about creating space, clarity, and trust for people who might already be overwhelmed.

My process was deliberately measured. I focused on building something that felt calm and grounded, both visually and structurally. Using Next.js gave me flexibility around performance and future expansion, while Firebase Auth allowed me to wire up real authentication early without overcomplicating the stack. I treated the announcement page less like a marketing artifact and more like the first chapter of a longer product story—something stable enough to stand on its own, but ready to support what came next.
subtitle: Designing a calm, trustworthy entry point for community-driven support
summary: An announcement page built for TowardBetter.me using React, Next.js, and Firebase Auth, designed as a clear and trustworthy entry point into a community-focused platform. It was my first project after returning from Australia and set the tone for how I wanted to approach product and system design moving forward.
title: TowardBetter.me — Announcement Page
name: TowardBetter.me — Announcement Page

description: This project is a modular toolkit designed to make working inside Obsidian more dynamic and visual. It includes a dashboard system modeled after how Next.js handles routing, turning your folder structure into a navigable home view that mirrors the way web frameworks organize content. Alongside it is QueueCards, a note queueing system that helps prioritize ideas, tasks, or references by tracking how often items are skipped. Together, they create a workspace that’s both structured and adaptable, aimed at people who like to think in systems and want their vault to feel more like a living interface than a static archive.
story: I built this collection out of curiosity about what it would look like if a note vault could behave like a web app. I’d been working with Next.js and liked its clean, predictable routing model, so I brought that idea into Obsidian, building a dashboard that treated folders as routes and notes as pages. Around the same time, I started experimenting with QueueCards, which became an early version of what would later become my app Top Note. This earlier version stayed fully local—everything lived inside Obsidian—but it taught me a lot about how people manage unfinished thoughts. Looking back, it was less about building tools and more about understanding how I think when the tools get out of the way.
subtitle: The-2nd-Best-Obsidian-Collection
summary: A modular Obsidian toolkit that turns your vault into an interactive dashboard and adds a simple queue system for managing notes. It’s an experiment in blending web-style structure with personal note-taking.
title: Obsidian Toolkit
name: Obsidian Toolkit

items.label: How I use Top Note
items.summary: Adding multiple widgets

items.label: Old Version - in app
items.summary: Iterating UI

items.label: Old Version - widgets
items.summary: Iterating UI

description:
Top Note is a focused productivity app for people who tend to ignore reminders or feel weighed down by long to-do lists. It takes a simpler approach: one reminder, flashcard, or note at a time. You can complete it or skip it, and if you skip, it returns sooner through a spaced repetition system that keeps important things visible.

This design encourages accountability and steady progress. It helps build habits, strengthen memory, and keep personal ideas within reach—without the noise of endless lists.

Why it works
Top Note combines two familiar ideas: single-task focus and spaced repetition. Together they keep your attention on what matters next, reinforcing memory and consistency over time.

Features
– One-at-a-time reminders that reduce distraction.
– Skip and repeat so skipped items return sooner.
– Spaced repetition flashcards for better recall.
– Widget-first design that keeps the app close at hand.
– Flexible note support for quotes, goals, or brief thoughts.
– Simple setup inside the app; most use happens in the widget.

Best for
– People who often dismiss reminders.
– Habit tracking and reinforcement.
– Short study or review sessions.
– Keeping a meaningful note visible through the day.

Top Note makes productivity manageable by narrowing your focus. Instead of managing a list, you engage with one small task—and let time handle the rest.
subtitle: A widget based iOS app
summary: A widget-first productivity app that keeps you focused on what's next and only on what’s next.
title: Top Note
name: Top Note

description: The first version of my portfolio came from following Corey Schafer’s Flask tutorials and trying to understand how a real web app fits together. I set up my own server, configured Nginx, and handled deployment myself—mostly because I didn’t know there were easier options. It took a lot of trial and error, but it taught me how everything actually works behind the scenes. I added some of my own SVG graphics and simple animations to make it feel personal. It wasn’t perfect, but it ran, and I learned a lot from getting it there.
story: I found “data scientist” on Indeed and thought it looked like something I’d enjoy, so I started teaching myself Python. Once I understood the basics, I needed a way to show what I could do. I followed Corey Schafer’s Flask tutorials and tried to build my own version, which meant learning about servers, Nginx, deployment, and all the setup that comes with it. I didn’t realize how complicated I was making things, but working through it taught me more than the tutorials themselves. When I finally got it online, it felt like I had actually learned how things fit together.
subtitle: Built with Flask
summary: A Flask-based portfolio deployed manually with Nginx on a self-hosted server. Included custom SVGs, simple animations, and hand-configured routing and deployment. Functioned as an early full-stack project that introduced web app structure, hosting, and deployment fundamentals.
title: ZSDynamics V1.0
name: ZSDynamics V1.0

description: After digging deeper into data science, I wanted the portfolio to be more than a place to drop my work. So I added a simple email subscription so visitors could get updates, and I integrated Dashly for some lightweight analytics and visualization. It was a noticeable step forward for me—not just in the code, but in how I was thinking about the people visiting the site.

resources.label: Collection of all previous portfolio pages

story: Once the first version was up, I realized it needed to do more than just sit there. I added signup options for updates and built a few small tools to track engagement. By then I was approaching things more like a developer—less focused on the code in isolation and more on how someone might actually use the site. It was a small shift, but it made me realize I liked working at the intersection of users and data.
subtitle: Built with Flask
summary: This version turned the portfolio from a static project list into an interactive site with email subscriptions and built-in analytics to better understand user engagement.
title: ZSDynamics V1.1
name: ZSDynamics V1.1

description: While I was in Australia on a working holiday visa, I started noticing how often React showed up in job descriptions. I didn’t want to throw away the Python knowledge I already had, so I rebuilt my portfolio using Python on the backend and React on the frontend. It helped me connect what I knew with what I needed to learn and gave me a better sense of how a modern stack actually fits together.
story: Living in Australia made me pay more attention to what companies were prioritizing in new hires. React kept coming up, so I used my portfolio as a way to learn it. I kept Python for the backend and used React for the frontend, which forced me to learn how the two communicate. It updated the portfolio, but more importantly, it taught me how real-world applications blend multiple technologies.
subtitle: Built with Python and React
summary: A full-stack rebuild using a Python backend and a React frontend, created to modernize the stack while keeping existing Python experience in play. Developed during a working holiday in Australia, it featured responsive layouts, component-based design, and a structure suited for showcasing data-focused projects.
title: ZSDynamics V2.0
name: ZSDynamics V2.0

description: After I got more comfortable with React, I wanted to see how design choices and small interactions could change the experience. I built a feature that let users switch between themes and font styles. It wasn’t the most practical feature, but it taught me a lot and pushed me to pay more attention to how design decisions show up in real use. That curiosity drove most of what I built during this stage.
story: After I got more comfortable with React, I wanted to see how design choices and small interactions could change the experience. I built a feature that let users switch between themes and font styles. It wasn’t the most practical feature, but it taught me a lot and pushed me to pay more attention to how design decisions show up in real use. That curiosity drove most of what I built during this stage.
subtitle: Built with React
summary: Added interactive features such as a live theme and font selector to experiment with frontend flexibility. Focused on React state management, component communication, and styling behavior. Served as a small sandbox for improving overall frontend fluency.
title: ZSDynamics V3.0
name: ZSDynamics V3.0

description: In the latest version, I focused on making the site feel more refined. I experimented with parallax effects and smoother animations to understand how small design choices change the overall experience. I also created an SVG character of myself that shifts colors in light and dark mode, which made the site feel a bit more personal. At this point, the portfolio wasn’t just about showing projects—it was a way to see how my design and development skills had grown.

resources.label: Animated portfolio with parallax and dynamic SVGs

story: For this version, I spent time on the details. I added parallax scrolling, smoother animations, and an SVG self-portrait that adapts to light and dark mode. It let me pull together everything I’d learned—Python, React, design, and motion—into a single project that felt consistent. Each version ends up marking where I was in my learning, both in coding and in figuring out how to build something that keeps improving.
subtitle: Built with React
summary: A design-driven update centered on smoother motion, subtle parallax effects, and an adaptive SVG avatar. Combined earlier technical and design skills into a more polished, cohesive, and expressive version of the portfolio.
title: ZSDynamics v4.0
name: ZSDynamics v4.0

items.label: Personal Portfolio V4
items.summary: A Next.js-powered portfolio featuring server-side rendering, dynamic routing, and a more scalable, production-ready structure.

items.label: Personal Portfolio V3
items.summary: A fast and lightweight portfolio built with React and Vite, optimized for improved performance and developer experience.

items.label: Personal Portfolio V2
items.summary: A modern portfolio using a React frontend with a Python backend, introducing a fully separated client–server architecture.

items.label: Personal Portfolio V1.1
items.summary: An enhanced Flask-based portfolio improving on v1 with refined structure, better styling, and more efficient backend logic.

items.label: Personal Portfolio V1
items.summary: A foundational portfolio built with Python and Flask, focused on simple routing and clean server-side rendering.

items.label: TowardBetter
items.summary: The announcement page for a women’s community site.

description: Across these versions, you can see me going from basic experiments with servers and deployment to paying more attention to how things actually feel to use. What started as me trying to learn the fundamentals turned into a steady process of trying something, seeing what worked, and adjusting. Each version added a small piece—a backend tweak, a visual idea, a different layout—and the whole set basically shows how I learn by building, fixing, and trying again.
story: When I first started learning Python, I wanted a place to put what I was figuring out, even if it wasn’t great yet. The early versions were rough, and I made a lot of mistakes, but working through them helped me understand what I was doing. Every version taught me something new—sometimes about code, sometimes about design, sometimes just about slowing down and solving one problem at a time. By the latest version, it wasn’t about proving anything; it was just a clear record of how my skills grew as I kept building.
subtitle: A collection of my previous portfolio pages
summary: This collection brings together different versions of my portfolio, each one capturing how my design sense, presentation choices, technical skill, and even career direction have shifted and sharpened over time.
title: Frontend Collection
name: Frontend Collection
